snippet: Music from multiple composers is brought together in “The Armida Project,” a surreal Baroque pastiche.
abstract: Zachary Woolfe reviews premiere of opera The Armida Project, which features music from several Baroque composers, conceived and directed by Igor Konyukhov and starring soprano Julia Lima at the Angel Orensanz Foundation. Photo (M)a
lead_paragraph: The mythical Arab sorceress Armida has been a character in an epic poem; the subject of operas by composers like Lully, Rossini, Haydn and Dvorak; an archetypal abandoned woman and a metaphor for the dangerously alluring East; even, in a 2005 opera by Judith Weir, a television reporter on location in Iraq. But it is safe to say that she was never an assistant at a tailor's shop. Never, that is, until Friday evening, when ''The Armida Project,'' an odd, surreal Baroque pastiche, had its premiere at the Angel Orensanz Foundation on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Featuring arias by Handel, Vivaldi, Monteverdi and Broschi, connected by new Italian dialogue, the production retains little of the traditional Armida narrative except the name.

headline.main: A Woman Abandoned In a Story Often Told
